article.description: UTEP and Nevada couldn't decide the Western Athletic Conference title in 18 regular-season games, so they'll finish things with a winner-take-all tournament championship game.
article.headline: Miners will meet Nevada for bid
article.linkText: UTEP steps past Boise to make WAC final
article.story: FRESNO, Calif. (AP) -- UTEP and Nevada couldn't decide the Western Athletic Conference title in 18 regular-season games, so they'll finish things with a winner-take-all tournament championship game. Omar Thomas scored 21 points in 23 minutes and second-seeded UTEP pulled away in the second half of an 85-73 victory over Boise State in the WAC tourney semifinals on Friday night. Chris Craig scored 19 points and Jason Williams had 15 points and 10 rebounds as the Miners (24-6) advanced to face top-seeded Nevada in their first trip to the WAC tournament final since 1993. UTEP and Nevada, a 67-59 winner over Rice in the early semifinal, tied for the regular-season title to set up a showdown between the powerful Wolf Pack and the resurgent Miners, who have 18 more victories than last season. Both teams went 13-5 in conference play. "We haven't had too many blips so far," UTEP coach Billy Gillispie said. "It's been a great season for us, and we hope it's still going after tomorrow." The victory was another remarkable achievement for UTEP, which has made the biggest turnaround in school history and one of the best in conference history. "We were thinking about the next level, the postseason," Williams said. "That's all that's on our minds. We're trying to win it so everybody can know that we're the real WAC champion." But the Miners' first victory of the season over Boise State wasn't easy. The Broncos pulled within 66-63 on Coby Karl's fourth 3-pointer with four minutes left, but Thomas, Roy Smallwood and Craig hit two free throws apiece while the Broncos missed four free throws and a layup. The Miners hung onto the lead, making 14 of their 15 free throws in the final four minutes as Boise State fouled constantly. "We kept coming at them, but we just couldn't catch up," said second-leading scorer Aaron Haynes, a Fresno native who scored 11 points on 4-of-11 shooting. "They're a good team, and they know how to take us out of our game sometimes." Bryan Defares scored 16 points and Karl had 12 before fouling out for Boise State (21-9), which won both regular-season meetings between the teams. The Broncos' second loss in 12 games was rooted in poor shooting: They were 11-for-37 early in the second half, and their strong finish began too late. Boise State expects an NIT bid, as does fourth-seeded Rice. The Broncos haven't reached the NCAA tournament or the NIT since 1994. "I think we've earned it. I think we deserve it," Boise State coach Greg Graham said. "We've done everything we should need to do to get into the postseason. I think we outdid most expectations, both us and UTEP." The Broncos shot just 32 percent in the first half, yet trailed by just one point at halftime. UTEP opened the second half with a 10-2 run, and Filiberto Rivera accidentally banked in a 3-pointer with 5:57 left, giving the Miners a 66-55 lead. Thomas, a junior-college transfer who comes off the bench for UTEP, hit six of his first seven shots and also finished strong, scoring 11 points in the second half. Boise State eliminated host Fresno State on Thursday night -- and probably killed the Bulldogs' chances of making money on the tournament. With no home team to support, there were perhaps 4,000 fans at the sparkling Save Mart Center for the evening session, with the upper bowl sitting completely empty. Former Milwaukee Bucks coach George Karl was in attendance watch his son Coby, a freshman guard for Boise State. Coby Karl hit back-to-back 3-pointers in the first half. Former Fresno State coach Jerry Tarkanian also attended, sitting in the front row.
